page.title: 02WILDLIFE IN THE AREA
page.content: There is a large area of open countryside in the area between Feering and Coggeshall Hamlet. Much of this is farmland, but there is wildlife supported by the hedgerows, the roadside verges and the Blackwater Valley. There are many species of plants, including many wild grasses and wild flowers; such as vetches, ox-eye daisies, poppies and campion. Many of the more common bird species can be found here too, including skylarks, wood pigeon and, in the summer, house martins and cuckoos. Occasionally a kestrel may be seen hovering over a roadside verge in search of food. The farmland itself is kept clear of these things by spraying,for insects and weeds, and the use of scarecrows and kites to keep birds away from crops.
